awd_titl_txt: D3SC: CDS&E: Learning molecular models from microscopic simulation and experimental data
awd_abstract_narration:
Cecilia Clementi of Rice University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry to develop multiscale models for macromolecular systems.   Professor Clementi and her group are developing machine learning tools to combine the results from microscopic simulation and experimental data into a data-driven modeling framework. The last several years have seen an immense increase in high-throughput and high-resolution technologies for experimental observation.  These advances are combined with high-performance techniques to simulate molecular systems at a microscopic level resulting in vast and ever-increasing amounts of data. Professor Clementi is taking advantage of this abundance of data and uses machine learning to extract information, in order to formulate general principles regulating the behavior of molecular systems. Understanding chemical processes at the molecular level is essential for a large number of applications, from energy storage to drug design. Additionally, as the need to represent massive data sets in terms of a model bears similarity across different fields, Professor Clementi's work may have an impact on a broad range of completely different disciplines from genomics to finance. This research impacts an interdisciplinary community of students and researchers. Her project includes the development of undergraduate and graduate courses, and outreach activities focused in the recruiting and mentoring of minority students, especially through collaboration with the Tapia Center at Rice University.

Professor Clementi is developing a data-driven framework to design effective molecular models at multiple resolutions, to address questions currently out of reach to existing computational and experimental approaches. The main idea is to use state-of-the-art machine learning methods to "learn" the coarse-grained dynamical models governing molecular systems (structure, thermodynamics, and kinetics/mechanism) at the mesoscale, by combining simulation data generated from microscopic simulation, and experimental data. By integrating different sources of data, this modeling approach reconciles bottom-up and top-down methods. This approach generates functional building blocks that can be embedded in higher-order simulations in order to bridge the gap to macroscopic systems. This modeling framework may serve as a keystone to integrate vast amounts of chemical data into quantitative, mechanistic and comprehensible models. Such models may explain how different molecular components organize and interact as a function of time and space in performing functions at the macroscopic scale. In particular, the developed framework is applied to investigate one specific biomolecular process: the binding of peptides to Major Histocompatability Complex (MHC) proteins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We proceeded in parallel to develop a bottom-up and a top-down approaches. We have developed methodologies to design coarse-grained models by using atomistic simulations (bottom-up) or by using experimental data (top-down). It is our ultimate goal to eventually join these parallel efforts into the definition of coarse-grained models from atomistic simulations augmented to reproduce all available experimental data.

1) Bottom-up approach

We are using machine learning to design protein models at resolution coarser than atomistic, but able to reproduce the free energy landscape of atomistic models. In 2019 we have published a manuscript in ACS Cent. Sci. where we proposed to use artificial neural network (CGnet) to learn coarse-grained force-fields from atomistic simulations. This work is having a large impact (it has already been cited ~70 times since its publication in April 2019) and many groups are contacting us to collaborate on different applications. This past year we have showed that it is also possible to design coarse-grained force-fields by using kernel methods instead of artificial neural network. We have compared the performance of the two approaches and found different regimes where one or the other is more efficient or accurate. We have published a manuscript (J. Chem. Phys. 152, 194106 (2020)) reporting the results of this study.

 

Additionally, we have developed a software package to allow the broader community to use our machine-learning-guided bottom-up coarse-graining on different systems. We have released the software in July 2020 (https://github.com/coarse-graining/cgnet), and we will continue to implement new functionalities into it as our methods evolve.

We are also delving deeper into the inner working of CGnet to understand the physical and chemical reasons for its success. We have decomposed the energy function resulting from the neural network into 2-body, 3-body, 4-body, and higher-body interactions, to understand the relative importance of the different terms. Interestingly, we find that 2-body and 3-body interactions are not sufficient to reproduce the correct free energy landscape of a protein system with a coarse-grained model and 4-body interactions are needed. This result has important consequences for the development of coarse-grained models and highlight the key role of machine learning in modeling non-trivial and multi-body functional forms. We are finalizing a manuscript for publication on these results.

 

Finally, a very important development during this year has been the extension of CGnet into a transferable architecture. CGnet in its original formulation represents an important result, as it shows the feasibility of a machine-learning-based coarse-graining approach, but it?s limited in its practical application as it is model dependent and requires atomistic simulation data of the system under study. This fact presents a problem for the study of large systems that cannot be simulated at atomic resolution for a sufficiently long time. In order to overcome this limitation, we have now redesigned CGnet by combining it with the SchNet network architecture, originally proposed to define classical force-field from quantum chemistry data. This new version (that we named CGSchNet) allows now to learn a transferable energy function. We have tested the transferability by designing a coarse-grained force field trained on a large set of peptides and we have obtained very exciting results: we can correctly recover the configurational landscape of the peptides not included in the training set, proving that the model learns an energy function that depends on the protein sequence and correctly account for the interactions among the different residue types. We are preparing these results for publication. We believe this is the first instance of a coarse-grained model that is transferable across such a large sequence space, and it is a key result for the further development of this approach.

 

2) Top-down approach

We are using a maximum-likelihood approach to incorporate experimental data into the design of coarse-grained and multi resolution protein models. We published a paper in 2018 where we first proposed the idea and we illustrated it on a simple system and synthetic data. We have now extended the methodology to use real experimental data from different sources. We have used free energy differences upon mutations on the protein ubiquitin to train a coarse-grained model for this protein. The model can reliably and robustly reproduce the mutagenesis data, and indicates the residue-residue interactions that are most important for the stability, folding, and dynamics of this protein. We are preparing these results for publication. We are also extending the approach to use results from NMR or FRET experiments in the training of the computational model, and to combine the data from mutagenesis, NMR, and FRET all together in the definition of an integrative model, that can be used to study protein dynamics when structural information is not available. We are now planning to use neural networks rather than fixed functional forms for the model energy functions, capitalizing from the results described above.
